greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Binomial(n+p, n) mod n, where p=4.
comment: Let d(m)...d(2)d(1)d(0) be the base-n representation of n+p. The relation a(n)=d(1) holds, if n is a prime index. For this reason there are infinitely many terms which are equal to 1.
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: a(n)=1 if n is a prime > 4, since binomial(n+4,n) == (1+floor(4/n))(mod n), provided n is a prime.
if n mod 24 == 0, then a(n) = n/12 + 1.
if n mod 24 is in {3, 9, 15, 18, 21}, then a(n) = n/3 + 1.
if n mod 24 is in {4, 20}, then a(n) = n/4 + 1.
if n mod 24 is in {8, 16}, then a(n) = 3*n/4 + 1.
if n mod 24 is in {14, 22}, then a(n) = n/2 + 1.
program: (MAGMA) [Binomial(n+4,4) mod n: n in [1..100]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Apr 27 2014
results.author: _Hieronymus Fischer_, Sep 30 2007
